body:
I regularly use the `spack concretize` command to get a sense of what `spack install` will do in environment before I actually run it. This is especially important when using upstreams, as you really want to make sure you're using upstream packages. I felt the command needed some improvement.

This merge request:
 - Adds documentation for what the 'package status' glyphs mean. 
 - Changes the glyphs to be a bit more obvious
   - All are in square brackets `[-]` and bold.
   - Installed is now `[✔]`
   - Missing is now `[?]`
   - Upstream is now blue.
 - Updated the corresponding glyph that's written when installing to a checkmark.
 - Install status now also checks that the install location exists.
 - Added a `-d/--dry-run` option to `spack concretize`, to see the tree without
   actually updating the spack.lock file.

![Screenshot from 2020-05-06 12-05-25](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/51765748/81212382-121b5600-8f92-11ea-9dcb-885f393cadf7.png)
title: spack concretize: use glyphs for spec status
